msIdentifier.repository: Gonville and Caius College, Lower Library
msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 457/395

summary.seg: This manuscript contains a large collection of Middle English and Latin medical, alchemical, and household recipes alongside charms and practical magical instructions to ward off vermin and other animals.

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Medieval Manuscripts Specialist
Cambridge University Library

msItem.title: Blessings
msItem.incipit: 1r 'Jhesus preser you and lyfe you', 'Benedictus qui venit in Nomine'
msItem.note: Added by two different hands
Full transcription.

msItem.title: Title inscription
msItem.incipit: 1rBooke of Fisike
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Charm against rats
msItem.rubric: 1v ffor to gedryn Ratownys and dryve þem from a place
msItem.incipit: 1v I commaunde alle the Ratoyns þat arn in this place withinne and witoute
msItem.explicit: 1v dominus deus sabaott be the whiche this place ye kepe ffrom alle wykkyd whehtes and ffrom alle Ratonys and alle odyr aventorys In nomine patrys et filij et spiritus sancti Amen

msItem.title: Charm against fever
msItem.incipit: 3v ffor a ffeuer

3v Take mowsere both þe leeffe and þe roote and bray it þe quarte off iij sponfull þan lett a prees say þe ouer iiij gospellys of þe iiij euangelistes and spryng holy water ther ouer þan vse it iij days ffastyng euery day a sponfful þat gete þe a hete with goyng orlyyng euery day þere afftyre
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Charm against fevers
msItem.incipit: 4r In nomine Christi omnipotens sempiterne deus qui ffecisti manum beato petro apostolo fac mihi famulo tuo .N. ut non amplius nec calores nec frigores habeant potestatem super me
msItem.explicit: 4r Coniuro vos febres que estis septem sorores prima vocatur yllya secunda sitillia tercia coyllia quarta soffocalia quinta sincia sexta genena septiam

msItem.title: Charm for healing toothache
msItem.incipit: 4v Take an herbe þat men calle sperward and make a cros þer off
msItem.explicit: 4v Say he [sic] fyue pater noster[is] and fyue Aveis while þat ye makyth þe cros and whan he gothe to bedde say xv iij ave maria etcaetara

msItem.title: Charm for staunching a bleeding wound
msItem.incipit: 4v Take a penne or a strawe and wryte þis iij wordes with the same blode above the wounde + agla + agla + aglos + otheos ++ it xal staunche with the grace of god Amen
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Charm against hallucinations and evil spirits
msItem.incipit: 5r Tak betayne and seynt mary leke gaderyd betwix seynt mary daye and bere it aboute and þer xal no spirits touche þe nor do þe non harme
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Charm for staunching a bleeding wound
msItem.rubric: 8r ffor to staunche bledyng sey þis iij tymys and iij pater noster[is]
msItem.incipit: 8r Christus in bethlem natus est: in Jordane batizatus est: Iordanis aquas ffecit stare Sic faciat tuum sanguinem cessare .N.
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Charm for staunching a bleeding wound
msItem.incipit: 8r Johannis baptista decollatus est latus Christi a longuino milite perforat est
msItem.explicit: 8r Sicut uerum credimus quod sancta maria uerum inffantem genuit Christum Sic retrahat vena sanguinem suum In nomine patris etcaetera

msItem.title: Charm against acute fever
msItem.incipit: 8v Tak iij bolyis or iij almaundys wryte with a pynnys poynt vpon þe ffyrst oblyi pater est vita and gyff yt to þe seke þe ffyrst day
msItem.explicit: 8v And al þese must be wreten withouten any tetyl aboven and euery off þe iij days v pater noster[is] and v Aveis and a crede and be hole with goddys grace

msItem.title: Charm against toothache
msItem.rubric: 64r A good charme ffor the toþe ache
msItem.incipit: 64r Dominus noster jhesus Christus super petram marmoriam sedebat
msItem.explicit: 64r vt non habeas potestatem ueri istum hominem vel mulierem N neque in capite neque in vllo loco corporis sui nocere valeas. Adiouro te per illum qui passus est pro nobis in cruce Amen

msItem.title: Charm against migraine
msItem.incipit: 86r In nomine patris et filij et spiritus sancti Amen Christus vincit + Christus imperat + Christus vos deffendat ab omni malo
msItem.explicit: 86r Et sacerdos dicat oracionem per pacient infirmo deus qui caritatis cum se ?oracione et post communio huiusmodi in sua missa cum prima oracione sue misse s[...] uno per dominum

msItem.title: Verse
msItem.incipit: 2rfolia voluere non ea frangere sit tibe cure / Inspice perlege bene conspice claude recede
msItem.note: Added in a different contemporary hand.
Full transcription.

msItem.title: Thirteen recipes for making ink of different colours
msItem.incipit: 2v ffor to make Reed take lyme ungueynt and put þerto water
msItem.explicit: 3r and ster it ofte when it is cold put in youre gumort
msItem.note: Collection of about 96 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Two recipes for killing birds
msItem.incipit: 5r Take vngueynt lyme and make lye þeroff
msItem.explicit: 5r and as many as ete þeroff shal not fle but deye etcaetera

msItem.title: Two alchemical recipes for making gilding
msItem.incipit: 6v A water for to gelde syluer oþer coper: Take newe leid eyryn and rost hem or sethe hem hard
msItem.explicit: 6v whan a drope wyll thirlen a tyn foyle þan it is good þan lett it kele and put it in bladderis and kepe it in bladderis

msItem.title: Alchemical recipe for writing without ink
msItem.incipit: 6v Item ffor to wryte withoute ynke take þe poudyr off coprose and robbe yt on clene paper and þenne take þe poudyr off galle and rubbe þerouer and þenne take ffayr watris and depe a penne þerinne and wryte vpon þe paper and yt wyll schewe blakke letteris
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Recipe for oil of Exeter
msItem.incipit: 10v The maner how oyle off exceter shulde be made
msItem.explicit: 11r In þe ffirste begynnyng off þe moneþe off maye take i [pound] or ij off flouris of cowslyppys and put þem in swete oyle de olyfe
msItem.finalRubric: 11rand be þe sure hit is a noble and sure oynement to dystroye alle ache on mannys body or lyme except goutes etcaetera

msItem.title: The Wise Book of Philosophy and Astronomy (Variant version)
msItem.incipit: 13r Here bygynneth the book of astronomye and phelosophie contryved and and [sic] mused by the wises phelisofers that euer wern sithen that the world began
msItem.explicit: 17r the first hwore of the nyght next swyng is mercoury the ijde the mone the iijde saturne the iiijthe iubiter the vthe marsthe vjte the sone the vijvenus the viijthe mercoury the ixthe the mone the xthe saturne the xjthe mars
msItem.note: Variant version interpolated with The Book of Ypocras (see below).
See IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 94 for other texts.

msItem.title: The Book of Ypocras
msItem.incipit: 14v ffirst as it is to know it is nedefull to take kepe of the Mone when that he is at the full ffor then wexeth the blood in man and woman and marow and brayn of other humours
msItem.explicit: 16r-16v while the Mone is in this signe for it is vncurable that is to say: If the Sonne or Mars or Saturne but afterward the signes so past men may attend the which with the grace of god may helpe hym
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 94.

msItem.title: Tract on zodiacal signs and associated maladies
msItem.incipit: Now whereas it is determyned the courses of the xij signes the iiij elementis the vij planetis as they reygne dayly the complexions of man
msItem.explicit: astronomyens and phelosophers sith aristotell ipocras or plato which hath complied [sic] and studyed this book made in actraite to know how a man shuld werk as well in phesyk as in surgery to avoyde and to conddissend all bad humours in man to deprave and avoyde

msItem.title: Note on amounts of tax and tithe due
msItem.incipit: 17v The summe of þe taske is xxxviij Mlo Co and liiij li x d ob. / The summe of þe dymys is xviij Mlo vj Co xxxviij li vj d ob.
msItem.note: Full transcription; note added in a later 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of seventy-five medical and household receipts
msItem.incipit: 18r First how the ach in the hed if so be that it be of the mygrayn then it will take diuers parties of the hed
msItem.explicit: 21r washe thy her wel therwith and bene then if ther be eny plaas that is herelese tak and anoynt it with the blod of a bak
msItem.note: Attributed to Aristotle in the rubric, probably referring to his Physics.

msItem.title: Tract on the virtues of herbs
msItem.textLang: Latin (10 herbs) and Middle English (35 herbs)
msItem.rubric: 22r Incipit liber secundus aristotelis 1534 Maser de cognicione herbarum
msItem.incipit: 22v Igitur virtutes et naturas singulorum debemus agnoscere
msItem.explicit: 25r medeworte is on iij maners and all hath one maner vertu is is hote and dry in both degrees and if it be with peper and mirre dronken togedir and dry in both degrees and that thu anoynt thy gomes therwith it doth away the stynk of the toth recipe and put in thy mowt and it doth away the tothwerk
msItem.note: Not a translation of Macer's Floridus de viribus herbarum; on the text, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), pp. 95-96.

msItem.title: Notes on perilous days for eating birds and bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 27v ffor gose etynge: These be þe fforeboden days ffor etyng gose or peion vpon peyne off his wellfare
msItem.explicit: 27v These be þe forbodyn days ffor bledyng: The laste daye off aprille þe ffurste daye off Auguste and þe ffurste day off Septembre
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 97.

msItem.title: List of names of herbs
msItem.rubric: 32r These be the sondry namys off erbys þat have ij or iij or iiij namys
msItem.incipit: 32r Consolyda þe maior þat ys comffery
msItem.explicit: 32r Broþerwort þat is puliolle þe monteyn

msItem.title: Tract on surgery
msItem.incipit: 34r Now ye haue herd the determinaciouns of phesyk of medcyns ayenst all maner of ivellis within the menbres of man and in the body of man inwardis as in drynkis in letwards in powderis and in suripe now shal we determyne be praktike of surgery to avoyde the superfluitees regnyng of appostemacions outwardis or othere hurtes of eny menbres
msItem.explicit: 34r This Rewle is generalle for alle maner of Surgery of eny Appostemacions owtward

msItem.title: List of medicinal waters, oils, and unguents
msItem.incipit: 34r Colman wilt hele hote and cold
msItem.explicit: 34r Aqua Betayn is good for heryng and for alle maner of syknesse within the body

msItem.title: Warning against letting women see wounds sustained in war
msItem.incipit: 44r If a man be woundid be war lete no woman se þe wounde ffor yf so were þat sche hadde deled with a man withine xxiiijti ourys the same wounde of the man schuld breste owt on a bledyng þat yt were gret aventure off the mannys lyffe
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Tract of ointments for surgery and various ailments, followed by five recipes for treating wounds
msItem.incipit: 44r A syrugien worchyng craftely wheresoeuer he go shuld bere with hym these v maner of oynementis that is to wete basilicoum for materyng
msItem.explicit: 44v To clense blood owt of a mans body aftir that he is hurt and bled inward. Recipe: the rote of parselle ffenell the leves of isope centory and rew and put therto mustard alle these stamped the juse yef hym in wyn. Explicit

msItem.title: Advice for healthy living throughout the year
msItem.incipit: 46r Ther be .l. canicler days
msItem.explicit: 46v take mesure and non and non oþer for in mesure ys vertue and þat wylle holy men kepe
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 102.

msItem.title: Tract on the four humours
msItem.incipit: 46v Right as þer be iij elementis so þere be iij complexiouns according in all maner qualites to the iiij elementis
msItem.explicit: 46v fflematyke man ys slembry slepy slowe slowþefull and moche spyttyng dul and harde of wyll ffat vysage and white of colour
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 103.

msItem.title: Physiognomy, extracted from the Secretum Secretorum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Aristotle
msItem.incipit: 47r Alysaunder the gret conquerour in alle hys conquest and warres was rulyd by arystotille
msItem.explicit: 50r And þen þow schalt be praysed and be holde wyse before god moch e more for þan yeff the makyng of þy complexioun were yeffe alle to vertue for he þat is made most brytull and standyþe strengest schall most be thanked of god herto accordyþe Seint poule sayyng on þys maner no man schal be crouned but as he haþe lawfully and stalwortþy stryvyn
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 103.

msItem.title: Prognostications based on thunder in each month throughout the year
msItem.incipit: 50r Thundir in Janyver: signifieþe þat same yere grete wyndis plente of corn and batell par auenture
msItem.explicit: 50v thundir in decembre signifieþe þat same yere plente of corn and of whete pes and accorde in þe pepull
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 103.

msItem.title: Tract on twenty-four perilous days in the year

rubric.locus: De diebus nociuis per lunares menses

msItem.incipit: 50v In eche changyng of eche Mone bere .ij. days in whiche what thing euer be bygun late or neuer schal it come to þe inde and þoo days be perlius for mony thinges
msItem.explicit: 51v and þus þat yere sycurly þow schalt be wavshed from the ffeueres ffrom the ffallyng evyll and oþer goutis and gout ffesteres and fro lose of þy siȝt
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 104.

msItem.title: Tract on the reign of planets
msItem.incipit: 51v Euermore þus reignyþe planettis in her cors ffirst saturnus þan iubiter þan mars þan mars þan sol þan venus þan mercurie þan lune
msItem.explicit: 52r lune ys cause of moystere huge waterez and violent flodes
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 104.

msItem.title: Prognostications based on the weekday on which New Year's Day falls
msItem.rubric: 52r This suyng chapetle shewys how all þe ȝere ys ruled by þe ffirst day of ianyuer
msItem.incipit: 52r Yeff the first day of ianyuer be sonday þan wynter schal be good and warme
msItem.explicit: 53r ffrutis shal shewe and fayle shippys shull be in peryll sumdell moren of bestes mony schul be seeke but namely of the feuer trestian and old folke schall die
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), pp. 104-105.

msItem.title: Tract on the four humours and the four seasons, the four parts of the day and night, the four ages of man and the four pats of the human body
msItem.incipit: 53r Now take hede lerne and bewarre in the yere be iiij quateres rewled by the iiij complexons
msItem.explicit: 53v melancolie reignyþe in all the lymes fro the reignes downward
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 105.

msItem.title: Tract on the planets
msItem.incipit: 53v Saturnus houre ys good and stronge to all thinges þat askyþe strenþe only
msItem.explicit: 55r he haþe a lytull tere and an albugyn id est a white stryke in his eyen
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 105.

msItem.title: Introduction to Ptolemy and the Almagest
msItem.incipit: 55r Aftour þat Alysaunder the gret kyng conquerour of al the world was gon to Macedonye
msItem.explicit: 55v and þese iij be signes of wynter
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), pp. 105-106.

msItem.title: Bloodletting lunary
msItem.rubric: 55v De tempore secundum cursum lune minuendi luna
msItem.incipit: Luna i all the day to lett blode ys good but namely to fore vnder luna
msItem.explicit: 56r luna xxx bled not þat day by no way
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 106.

msItem.title: Tract on bloodletting based on the reign of the signs of the zodiac
msItem.incipit: 57r Thow schalt vnderstande þat euery quarter of þe Mone contenet in luna .vij. days fully
msItem.explicit: 57v piscis kepe þy feet and the vtter partiez of them. Explicit
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), pp. 106-107.

msItem.title: Tract on urines
msItem.incipit: 57v Rubicunda colour aqua as þe ius of pomeorounge wrogoun out: this bytokenyþe the same þat dyd þat oþer but not so sore
msItem.explicit: 60r and oþerwhile þe residence ys blacke and þen yef hyt be suche vren yt ys expulcioun of venomous mater and signifieþe deþe

msItem.title: Extract from a translation of French version of the Secretum Secretorum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Aristotle
msItem.incipit: 61v The body is dyuyded into iiij parties
msItem.explicit: 62v kepe the ffro other ffishis þat be grete and off hard skyn ffor suche ffishis be wyndy and this sufficethe as nowe
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 108.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Recipes for men and women 'that can not make water', for the stomach, and for staunching a bleeding wound ; Added in the the 16th century.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes include the dates 24 October 1617 and 30 May 1619
f. [63a] verso contains two notes preceded by the place name 'Teddington' concering payments to 'Thomas Cwsse' and 'Gregory Cadge'
Added by the same 17th-century hand that added the texts on f. [74a]recto-[74b]verso.

msItem.title: Instruction to prevent dogs from barking at you
Instruction to drive flies out of your house
Instruction to make dogs follow you
Instruction to make a woman fall in love with you
Instruction for creating the illusion of a hare and other animals
Prose lunary
msItem.incipit: 68r God off hys grace mad adam vppon þe ffyrst day off the mone in the vale off Ebrew
msItem.explicit: 74rthe wheche rule may not ffayle into þe day off dome but what perell be ordeynyd to man or woman god and good preyeres may defende yt ffro hem etcaetera. Explycyt

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: f. [74a]verso contains a note on prices for goods, including wheat and barley
Added by the same 17th-century hand that added the recipes on f. [63a] recto-[63b] verso.

msItem.title: Prognostications based on the weekday on which Christmas Day falls
msItem.incipit: 74r If Crystemesse day ffall vpon a Sonday þat schalle be an esy wynter
msItem.explicit: 75r and therffor knowe we oure god with good lenyng and thorwe hys mersy he wyl defende vs ffrom alle mysaventurys that schulde byfalle among vs by dyuerys tymys afftyr comyng
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 109.

msItem.title: Dieta ypocratis (English translation)
msItem.incipit: 75r In the monyth of ianuare let the not blood on the ffyrst day
msItem.explicit: 75vand in this monythe nyghe no ffyre thy thankys
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 109.

msItem.title: Tract on perilous Mondays
msItem.incipit: 75v That one is the ffyrste monday off ffevruare
msItem.explicit: 75v he soo þat ys born in eny off hem hys body schal neuer rote that ys ffor to seye the xij day of ianuare the xxiiijti day
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 110.

msItem.title: Note on the three Egyptian Days
msItem.incipit: 75v Tres dies sunt in anno in quibus non licet homini uel pecori sanguinem minuere seu porcionem accipere quia vix et numquam convalesset Scilicet prima dies lune Augusti et vltima dies lune Apprilis et vltima dies lune decembris
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.incipit: 77v Thys ys þe boke off ypocras in þis booke he techith ffor to knowe by what planete sykenesse lyffe and deth and þe tymys theroff
msItem.explicit: 78v þis rule is generall ffor al maner off surgyrye off postemys outeward here endyth the booke off Ipocrace off lyffe and dethe translatyd off astronomyerys the beste vpoun
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 111.

msItem.title: The Marvellous and Sotfast Cunning of Astrologie
msItem.incipit: 79r Here begynnythe the merveyllys and the sothffast kunnyng of astrologie ffounded and proued trewe cc yer or crist was borne by the gret philosopher tholomeus
msItem.note: For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), p. 111.

msItem.title: Zodiacal moonbook
msItem.incipit: 83v Here begynnyth þe mone off tholomee ffounden by olde doctryne off Astrologye more þan iij Ml wynter passide off gret Alysainder [sic] and oþer grett werryores and conquerroures
msItem.explicit: 83v and the clypsys þat here is icallyd dyssemale days þe astrolaboure or þe quadraunt þe wheche ffallythe
msItem.note: Ends mid-sentence due to the loss of a folio.
For other texts, see IMEP, vol 17 (2001), pp. 111-1112.

msItem.title: Note on the usefulness of this volume
msItem.incipit: 84v Thys boke off medesynes ys veri necessary and profytabull ffor soche as be languente or dolent ffor they haue i ben persuaded and proued vppon pascyens that haue bene restored too comfortabull state off body by soche as war prudent and wyse mynysters off the medesynes in thys present boke contaynyd so that the dolentes war desyruus too \be/ ordryd off after the aduyce off ther physycyouns ffor who that dothe the contrary can not haue the operacion off the medycyn acordyng to the sayng off wyse auncyant doctors of physyke: Qui contempuit medicum recusat sanitatem
msItem.note: Full transcription.

p.secFol: 2r ffor the hete in a legge or arme

supportDesc.support: Paper 1-67, 84 Tête de boeuf ( 65 30 ) in the centre of the folio, comparable to Briquet, nos 15044, 15097 . These examples are dated to 1455-1470. 68-83 Main ( 65 20 ) in the centre of the folio, not comparable to watermarks recorded in eitherBriquet or Heawood: a hand with a cross extending below the wrist.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of a select number of rectos: 5, 13, 15, 18, 25, 26, 28, 30, 34, 40, 45, 50, 55, 60, 65, 68, 70, 74, 79

collation.p: Due to the tightness of the binding, the collation of this manuscript has not been established.

supportDesc.condition: Brittle edges with much damage to the lower edges, particularly the lower right-hand corners. The first folios have been heavily gnawed by a rodent.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. 28-42 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in Gothic cursive with both Anglicana and Secretaryfeatures, by multiple hands from the second half of the 15th century and first half of the 16th century.

decoNote.p: Diagram of 12 urine bottles in brown ink on ff. 57v-58v
Large two- and three-line plain initials in red on ff. 13r-19r, ff. 26r-27r, ff. 29r-30r, ff. 31r-33r, ff. 34r-37v, ff. 38v-44v
Litterae notabiliores highlighted with red ink on ff. 13r-19r, f. 23r, ff. 26r-27r, ff. 29r-30r, ff. 31r-33r, ff. 34r-37v, ff. 38v-44v
Line filler in red ink on f. 14v-15r
Titles rubricated in red ink on f. 18r and f. 46r
Underlining in red ink on on ff. 13r-14v, f. 23r, ff. 26r-27r, ff. 29r-30r, ff. 31r-33r, ff. 34r-37v, ff. 38v-44v
The name 'Galyene' [Galen] has been written with cadels inside a banderol of red ink on f. 44r, where it serves as a header at the beginning of a medical text
Paraphs in red ink on on ff. 13r-19r, f. 23r, ff. 26r-27r, ff. 29r-30r, ff. 31r-33r, ff. 34r-37v, ff. 38v-44v
Drawing of a man in brown ink upside down at the top of f. 1v added in the late 15th- or early 16th-century hand.

binding.p: (?) Nineteenth-century paneled binding with a triple-line fillet border frame and central frame on brown leather over millboards, with plain pastedowns. Gonville and Caius College's armorial bookplate pasted on the inside of the upper cover inscribed with the classmark number '457' (black ink) and '395' (red ink). The spine features a gold-stamped title ('Medical Tracts'), the gold-stamped classmark '457' and both classmarks ('457' and '395') printed on labels.

origin.origDate: The main texts of the manuscript are written in late 15th- and early 16th-century hands.

p.name: GrymstonGrymston: their name in a prayer written in a early 16th-century hand on f. 3r: 'Jhesus Mary grymston'.
Thomas SowmanSowman, Thomas: his inscription in a 16th-century hand on f. 84r: 'y Thomas sowman of Raylegthe'; perhaps also inscribed the name 'Thomas' twice on f. 85r and once on f. 86v.
James HyllHyll, James: his name twice inscribed in a 16th-century hand on f. 86v: 'James Hyll / Kbmks Hkll' [a cipher].
John WhyteWhyte, John: his name inscribed in a 16th-century hand on f. 86v: 'John Whyte'.
Henry GoodeGoode, Henry: his ownership inscription in a late 16th- or early 17th-century hand on f. 1r: 'Henry Good Noui hosp[italis] Socius est verus possessor huius [libri]'.

history.acquisition: Perhaps given to the Gonville and Caius College by William Moore (bap. 1590-1659), librarian and collector of manuscripts Moore, William, bap. 1590-1659, as suggested by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936 in A descriptive catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, vol. 2 (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1908), p. 531. The College's classmark numbers have been gold-stamped, printed and inscribed on the covers, but the classmark '457' also features on f. [ii] verso (inscribed in pencil) and f. 1r (inscribed in ink).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by M.R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, 2 vols (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1908) and Kari Anne Rand Schmidt, Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge (Cambridge: Brewer, 2001).

availability.p: Visitors to Gonville and Caius College who wish to consult Lower Library material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Gonville and Caius College: Library Information.
